R: @dhalperi
I squashed and rebased onto tgroh's setup/teardown stuff, PTAL.
Also looks like there new methods are not supported in DoFnTester? If you have any tests using it, then you probably need to explicitly call setup/teardown?

Looks like this one slipped through the cracks because it had no reviewer assigned ;)

Can you rebase and I'll review?
@vikkyrk good point -- file a JIRA?

A bunch of nits. I scanned the tests and things seem in order. Are there any of the old tests that you know you removed (it didn't look like it).

Assuming not, once the nits are addressed this LGTM.

I'd like to see these moved into a package related to the reflection -- it would allow us to use package visibility to connect the pieces while using public to control what is visible to the runner/SDK. That can happen in this PR (which introduces the multiple reflection related classes) or a followup.

This provides API convenience to user and still uses Spark's native KafkaIO, essentially passing the configuration. I am not sure if that is a big improvement over current situation. In addition it is better if it is explicit to users that they are not using Beam KafkaIO.

Based on our discussion on email, it would be better to get Spark runner to support to Beam Unbounded sources. That way all of the Beam sources benefit. Even if there is a performance hit, I think that is useful. We can certainly look into improving how well Spark runner works for Beam. 

I am not sure of current state of Spark runner. will try to get more up to date.

I'm not sure I agree with @rangadi. Assuming that Spark's version of Kafka is indistinguishable to users from the Beam version of KafkaIO, it is nice to not need to change your pipeline when changing runners.

If Spark does not support `UnboundedSource` and can't do so quickly, this is a good solution. Even once Spark does support the API, it may still be better for users to override to the Spark-native solution if that brings much better performance (and as long as it is indistinguishable to users. If this is not the case, probably better to use the `UnboundedSource` implementation and log? rather than ignore silently or fail).
I was waiting for the rest of the datastore changes to get done, so that its easier to get this right in one shot. Will do it soon!

I am not against this PR going in. API portability is certainly useful for users. There are some cases of API not supported here, and we will have to explain the difference while replying to support questions on user lists, but not a big deal.

Better to update the title of the PR and the Jira to better reflect intention.

I think the PR title is accurate - currently, the SparkRunner actually provides it's own [KafkaIO](https://github.com/apache/incubator-beam/blob/master/runners/spark/src/main/java/org/apache/beam/runners/spark/io/KafkaIO.java) but the idea here is to be able to keep portability.
I am working on supporting `Read.Unbounded` and I'll have results by the end of the week, so let's keep this PR open for now.
Thanks.
LGTM
R: @dhalperi @charlesccychen
Thanks! LGTM.
We were trying to keep all the temp files inside the `/target/` subfolder so that they integrate nicely with maven's cleanup process. Can you say more about need / effect?

@dhalperi

With the current configuration cloning the repo and doing a `python setup.py sdist` fails with the following error:

`error: error in 'egg_base' option: 'target' does not exist or is not a directory`

This is a normal and expected user action hence that is the need.

What is actually happening is the custom override for `egg_base` is forcing the output to a non-existent `target` directory. And it fails because it does not exist. 

One way to fix this would be to have an empty `target` directory in the root (`sdks/python`). However I do not think that is the best option.

Removing the custom override for `egg_base` enables things. It also creates a new artifact (directory)  in the root called `apache_beam_sdk.egg-info`. This also can be improved by removing the overrides in `tox` config. By removing them we force that and all the testing related intermediate files to packed under `.tox` folder. We are trading one artifact folder with another.

Also note that with or without this change not everything is under the `target` folder, there is another artifact created by this process called `nose-1.3.7-py2.7.egg`.

My argument is it is better to not have config overrides, and have an additional `.tox` directory created as part of the `tox` run. We can improve the cleanup stage by removing `.tox` folder after executing `tox`. After all that directory is only used as the working directory by `tox` and does not have value beyond that.

After this change a `target` folder is still created, that contains the binary package.

Thanks, PTAL. I moved most things except DoFnAdapters to a .reflect package (couldn't move DoFnAdapters cause a few things needed for it to function are package-private in DoFn and I wouldn't want to make them public)

I'm not sure I follow why you need the annotations for those cases. If the
code has explicitly `ValueProvider<String>` it is available via
TypeDescriptor/TypeToken/reflection. It is only erased once you get a class.

The only place that would break down is something like:

```
public interface MyOption<T> {
  List<T> getFoo();
}
```

But I don't think that happens with our options framework...

On Tue, Aug 16, 2016 at 4:29 PM sammcveety notifications@github.com wrote:

> For Annotations, wanted to sketch my understanding. Like so?
> 
> @NestedClass(String)
> ValueProvider getFoo();
> 
> @NestedClass(String)
> List getFoo();
> 
> @NestedClass(String, Integer)
> Map getFoo()?
> 
> —

> .
Please review. R: @chamikaramj

bjchambers@, I don't believe your suggestion works out since the common case is to not put the type parameter on the interface definition. Also putting a type parameter there complicates how PipelineOptions extend each other.
LGTM

I went ahead and tried that, please let me know what you think.

With respect to IDs and threads, to confirm, the suggestion is to have a read-only getID() method on PipelineOptions, that is populated at creation time according to some routine that would guarantee its uniqueness?

Ignore my comment about the @Type annotation. bjchambers was correct that the type information is available.

Instead of manipulating the type information in ProxyInvocationHandler, you should annotate ValueProvider with @JsonDeserialize like PipelineOptions and create a Deserializer which looks at the typing information and finds the correct sub-type deserializer there, invokes it and returns a ValueProvider that wraps the deserialized value.

Hey Frank,

One problem here is that you have proposed merging into `master` instead of into `python-sdk`.

I've attached two screenshots that show what you did, and what you should have done, to get a clean PR. Note the circled red boxes and how clean the second one is.

Thanks for the contribution!

Don't propose merging into `master`:

My next fix should be to change the new-developer documentation so that it covers this case.

Using a transient ThreadLocal with an override on the initialValue would have been much cleaner:
https://docs.oracle.com/javase/7/docs/api/java/lang/ThreadLocal.html#initialValue()

initialValue is only called on first get() call per thread.

This PR adds a new method, `Create#empty` to address [BEAM-440](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/BEAM-440). As I explained in the JIRA ticket, I don't think adding a `TypeDescriptor` would be very clean, since the coder is available from the pipeline coder registry, but the transform is created before the pipeline is made available.

This is my first PR to this repo, so feedback is definitely appreciated. @dhalperi you created the issue, mind taking a look?

A few updates:
- Got tests to pass with roughly the current scheme, though the instanceof ParameterizedType check fails, casting doubt on whether that will work.  Any idea why?
- The reason the type information was in ProxyInvocationHandler was to support the internal marshalling that RuntimeValueProvider does.  Absent this logic, it seems like the marshalled call from RuntimeValueProvider to TestOptions.getFoo() will hit a path that causes us to try to deserialize a ValueProvider, which will return a ValueProvider<T>, not a T.
- Given that worker options are set at startup and the tests demonstrate the viability of this approach, is the ID/thread-local stuff still necessary?

[![Coverage Status](https://coveralls.io/builds/6157692/badge)](https://coveralls.io/builds/6157692)

Changes Unknown when pulling **2efe7617a595b8ac6167db40724d9874afd6df23 on francesperry:master** into *\* on apache:master**.
R: @chamikaramj

[![Coverage Status](https://coveralls.io/builds/6158380/badge)](https://coveralls.io/builds/6158380)

Changes Unknown when pulling **2efe7617a595b8ac6167db40724d9874afd6df23 on francesperry:master** into *\* on apache:master**.

- No, ParameterizedType seems like the right type it should be unless the method was defined with a rawtype (List vs List<String>) or wildcard or typevariable.
- Yes, the whole point is that you want to deserialize a ValueProvider. In the deserializer for the ValueProvider you need to use the requested type to pulling out the parameterized type to lookup the deserializer which you invoke and then wrap the result in a ValueProvider. Very similar to how our coders have component coders that are used to decode the internal type.
- Worker options are set at startup in Dataflow, can't assume how the system works everywhere.

I added a skeleton for the (de)serializer, but I'm not clear on where it would get the type information in the same way.  Specifically, in the context of the deserializer, where would I get the analog to Method.getGenericReturnType()?

Deserialization context should have access to everything so that you can get the JavaType. Should be the same java type that was constructed in the ProxyInvocationHandler

https://fasterxml.github.io/jackson-databind/javadoc/2.7/com/fasterxml/jackson/databind/DeserializationContext.html

I believe getContextualType should return the JavaType and findRootValueDeserializer should be relevant

Might be worthwhile to look at jacksons implementations of different deserializers for implementation guidance:
http://grepcode.com/file/repo1.maven.org/maven2/com.fasterxml.jackson.core/jackson-databind/2.6.0/com/fasterxml/jackson/databind/deser/std/CollectionDeserializer.java?av=f
LGTM
Thanks! R: @dhalperi

So getContextualType appears to be returning nullptr:

Caused by: java.lang.NullPointerException
    at com.google.common.base.Preconditions.checkNotNull(Preconditions.java:212)
    at org.apache.beam.sdk.options.ValueProvider$Deserializer.deserialize(ValueProvider.java:67)

Any ideas on that, and is the structure otherwise in line with what you'd expect?
Removed the ObjectMapper, like so?

Implement ContextualDeserializer to create the "typed" variant of ValueProvider deserializer.

You should have access to the JavaType then in createContextual

So this is including a type parameter in Deserializer?

Deserializer<T> extends JsonDeserializer<ValueProvider<T>> implements
ContextualDeserializer {
@Override createContextual(...) {
  type = [get type from from context]
  return new Deserializer<T>();
}
}

PipelineOptionsFactory isn't using getGenericReturnType when parsing around line 1400 which is an original bug and fixing it will add support for parsing generic types like `List<Integer>`

Adding a test for the `List<Integer>` case would be useful
